title: Tory MP's Brexit information request snubbed by EVERY North East university - Chronicle Live
text:

A Tory MP’s ‘Big Brother-style’ request for Brexit information has been given short shrift by North East universities. 
Conservative whip Chris Heaton-Harris wrote to UK vice-chancellors across the country asking for the names of professors lecturing on Brexit and details of their courses was researching a book, it has been claimed. 
But all in this region have acknowledged receiving the letter and none have said they will be providing the information requested. 
Professor Stuart Corbridge, vice-chancellor of Durham University , said: “We have received the letter. We did not reply. It suggests a challenge to academic freedom that I find alarming.” Read More Tory MP's Brexit letter - North East universities to ignore 'sinister' information request 
University of Sunderland’s vice-chancellor, Shirley Atkinson, commented: “One of the important roles of universities is to secure freedom of speech: fostering conversations and creating a safe environment that encourages students, employees and the community to debate and discuss matters of general interest. At the University of Sunderland we continue to protect and promote that role.” 
And a Northumbria University spokesperson said: “A letter was received by our vice-chancellor, and like other universities we do not intend to respond to it.” 
On Tuesday we revealed Newcastle University had taken the same line while Prof Thom Brooks, dean of Durham Law School, said: “Let me make something clear. I will NOT be answering his request. We’re a university. Not thought police.” Chris Heaton-Harris (Image: PA) 
Even those who defended Mr Heaton-Harris, one saying he might have been researching a book, admitted the letter “probably should not have been sent”. 
Universities accused the Leave-supporting MP of taking “the first step to the thought police” and branded the move a “sinister” attempt to clamp down on free speech. 
After being disowned by Downing Street, Mr Heaton-Harris tweeted: “To be absolutely clear, I believe in free speech in our universities and in having an open and vigorous debate on Brexit.” Read More
